name: Determinantal conjecture
summary: The determinantal conjecture, also known as the Marcus-de Oliveira conjecture, states that the determinant of the sum of two \(n\times n\) normal complex matrices, \(A\) and \(B\), must lie within the convex hull of a specific set of \(n!\) points. These points are formed by multiplying together the eigenvalues of \(A\) and \(B\) in all possible permutations. This conjecture is a significant open problem in matrix analysis.Â
head: A and B are two \(n	imes n\) normal complex matrices with eigenvalues \(\sigma (A)=\{a_{1},\dots ,a_{n}\}\) and \(\sigma (B)=\{b_{1},\dots ,b_{n}\}\) respectively.
tail: the determinant of their sum, \(\det (A+B)\), lies within the convex hull of the \(n!\) points given by the products \(\prod _{i=1}^{n}(a_{i}+b_{\sigma (i)})\) for all permutations \(\sigma \) in the symmetric group \(S_{n}\).
